Boomburst lets Kommo-o neutrally hit much of the metagame for large damage, which, when coupled with STAB Clanging Scales and Flamethrower as coverage for Steel-types, can easily break cores featuring the likes of Great Tusk, Skarmory, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and more. Bulletproof along with Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to wall Choice Scarf Tapu Lele looking to revenge kill it as well as set up in front of Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Tera Normal gives Kommo-o a stronger Boomburst, while Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and useful resistances to all of its weaknesses, allowing Kommo-o to take would-be checks, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, Baxcalibur, and Iron Valiant, by surprise and set up in front of them. However, Kommo-o likes to use its Tera and thus denies its teammates this option, and it can be checked by a well-timed Tera from Pokemon such as Tera Steel Garchomp and subsequently be revenge killed. It is also walled by the likes of Heatran, Garganacl, and Clodsire, which can tank its coverage options even without Terastallizing and cripple it with Toxic or Salt Cure or simply force it out and deny future setup opportunities. Finally, due to the nature of Kommo-o’s setup, it can only reasonably do so once per game, making Kommo-o more suited for offensive teams. Thus, having allies that can take care of Kommo-o’s defensive checks before it sets up can allow it to do its job much more effectively; physical attackers like Iron Valiant, offensive Landorus-T, and Samurott-H can pressure and remove checks for Kommo-o to break and potentially sweep. Hazard support is also valuable in preventing opponents from switching back and forth between Pokemon in a Regenerator core; in particular, Assault Vest Tornadus + Toxapex; Pokemon like Great Tusk and Garchomp can set up Stealth Rock to pressure switches.

Belly Drum.description: With Belly Drum, Kommo-o becomes a fearsome sweeper capable of wiping unprepared teams with relative ease. The HP cuts from Substitute and Belly Drum will immediately activate Salac Berry, giving Kommo-o maximum Attack along with increased Speed to sweep offensive and defensive teams alike. Substitute also allows Kommo-o to dodge status moves like Ferrothorn’s Leech Seed, Garganacl's Salt Cure, Landorus-T's Toxic, and Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp that could potentially ruin Kommo-o’s sweep, instead giving it a free set up opportunity. Drain Punch is chosen over heavier hitting moves like Close Combat, as the extra damage is not needed, and Drain Punch can heal off the HP lost through Belly Drum and Substitute, making Kommo-o harder to revenge kill. Thunder Punch is used to dent and possibly KO common defensive tanks that can survive Drain Punch, like Skarmory, Toxapex, Tera Water Garganacl, Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Bulletproof stacked on top of Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to surprise opponents like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Dragapult looking to revenge kill it. Although Soundproof blocks moves such as Roar from defensive Garchomp and Bug Buzz from Volcarona, it is generally not preferred due to the lack of relevant sound-based moves in comparison to the bevy of aforementioned qualities gained from Bulletproof. Tera Electric can power up Thunder Punch with STAB to score KOs on the likes of Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Tera Fairy Kingambit, while Tera Steel gives it useful resistances that may allow it to reach Salac Berry range without Substitute by tanking a resisted hit from the likes of Tapu Lele or Mega Diancie. Belly Drum Kommo-o fits on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to sweep or clean up teams once its checks are removed. Therefore, it appreciates partners that can lure and remove Pokemon like Clodsire, Tera Grass Heatran, Gliscor, and Landorus-T that check it; Tapu Koko in particular is good, as it can run Hidden Power Ice to bait and KO the latter two and badly chip the former two potentially into Kommo-o’s range while also boosting the power of its Thunder Punch by setting Electric Terrain. Belly Drum Kommo-o also has trouble setting up, as it mainly uses the element of surprise to get up a Substitute —namely, it exploits the opponent's fear of Clangorous Soulblaze and thus forces them to switch. Thus, it appreciates dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl in order to more consistently set up Belly Drum.

Offensive Pivot.description: Thanks to its great Speed, power-boosting ability in Electric Terrain, and access to both U-turn and Volt Switch, Tapu Koko functions as a great offensive pivot. It often utilizes its ability to force out slower foes like Mega Charizard Y, Alomomola, and Hisuian Samurott to safely pivot in wallbreakers that take advantage of Electric Terrain like Iron Valiant, Iron Boulder, and Iron Moth in safely via U-turn or Volt Switch. U-turn is usually favored for its consistency against Ground-types like Gliscor and Clodsire and ability to deal more chip damage to Grass-type Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Serperior; alternatively, Volt Switch has higher damage output and avoids contact punishment from Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Volcarona, but being blocked by Ground-type Pokemon makes it less reliable. Hidden Power Ice targets popular Ground-type such as Landorus-T and Gliscor and is the preferred option over Dazzling Gleam. Heavy-Duty Boots complements Tapu Koko's frequent pivoting by negating entry hazard damage, while Electrium Z lets it pick off weakened foes such as Galarian Slowking, Heatran, and Volcarona. Due to its typing and mediocre Special Attack stat, Tapu Koko struggles with bulky Ground-type Pokemon like Clodsire and Ting-Lu, as well as sturdy walls like Galarian Slowking, Garganacl, and Ferrothorn; therefore, it needs powerful teammates like Mega Medicham, Iron Valiant, and Hawlucha to break through them. Those teammates also appreciate Tapu Koko checking faster offensive threats such as Tornadus-T, pressuring walls such as Toxapex, and generating momentum for them to make use of. Tapu Koko also has great synergy with the likes of Iron Crown, Landorus-T, and Iron Moth, forming the infamous VoltTurn combo. In the case of Iron Moth and Iron Crown, Tapu Koko’s Electric Surge activates Quark Drive for them. In return, they take care of Tapu Koko’s checks such as Ferrothorn and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele.

Choice Specs.description: Since Tapu Koko is commonly seen as a mere Terrain setter and pivot, it can catch opponents off guard with Choice Specs, luring in Ground-types like Landorus-T and Gliscor and heavily denting them with Hidden Power Ice. Once Ground-types are eliminated, Tapu Koko can also start spamming Volt Switch to overwhelm foes, dealing large amounts of chip damage to facilitate a sweep from allies like Iron Valiant. Additionally, its high Speed and Electric Surge allow it to function as a fast pivot that enables Quark Drive Pokemon such as the aforementioned Iron Valiant and Iron Moth. Dazzling Gleam is a secondary STAB move that can be used as a safe mid-ground option to hit Ground-types for decent damage when using Hidden Power Ice is risky, and it also hits foes like Mega Latias and Zamazenta harder than Tapu Koko's other moves. Tera Electric allows Tapu Koko to clean up with Thunderbolt once Electric-immune foes are defeated, but Tapu Koko should still primarily be used as an enabler for allies like Iron Valiant and Iron Crown and thus should generally not waste Tera. Choice Specs Tapu Koko should be paired with allies that benefit from Landorus-T's and Gliscor's absences. For example, Iron Crown has a much easier time setting up without worrying about a stray Earthquake, Iron Moth has trouble with Gliscor and benefits from its absence as well as the presence of Electric Terrain, Hawlucha becomes a deadly sweeper with one of its biggest checks removed, and Iron Valiant's Swords Dance variants become very potent without Landorus-T to stop them. There are a few defensive Pokemon, such as Galarian Slowking and Ferrothorn, that can stop Tapu Koko easily; therefore, teammates that can threaten these foes such as Weavile and Iron Moth are useful. Finally, entry hazards are useful to whittle down Gliscor into KO range of Hidden Power Ice, so Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Iron Treads, and Landorus-T are useful.

Dual Screens.description: Access to Light Screen and Reflect alongside an excellent Speed tier allows Tapu Koko to function as an effective dual screens setter in hyper offense teams. Taunt is a powerful tool on Tapu Koko, allowing it to prevent the use of Defog from the likes of Tornadus-T and Corviknight, deny setup from Pokemon such as Volcarona, Ogerpon-W, and Raging Bolt, and prevent opposing leads, such as Landorus-T and Ribombee, from setting up entry hazards. Tera Ghost is used solely for blocking Rapid Spin from Great Tusk, whereas Tera Flying allows Tapu Koko to safely set up dual screens in front of Ground-type Pokemon such as Gliscor and Landorus-T, though it should be noted that Tapu Koko rarely Terastallizes. Tapu Koko's Electric Surge is a powerful tool, allowing Hawlucha to reliably activate Unburden while also activating Quark Drive from the likes of Iron Valiant, Iron Crown, and Iron Boulder. Setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor appreciate Tapu Koko's dual screens, which allow for easier setup. Defog is able to remove Tapu Koko's dual screens and Electric Terrain, making Serperior, Encore variants of Iron Valiant and Ogerpon-W, and Taunt from Hisuan Samurott and Landorus-T solid options to use alongside Tapu Koko, as they can punish Defog users. Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Iron Moth are able to outspeed and threaten to KO Tapu Koko, making teammates that can take advantage of them, such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gyarados, and Dragonite, excellent partners.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is the premier speed control option in the tier, outrunning and OHKOing common offensive threats such as Speed Booster Energy Great Tusk, Swords Dance Urshifu-R, and non-Booster Energy Iron Valiant. Additionally, Psychic Terrain blocks priority moves like Mega Lopunny's Fake Out and Weavile's Ice Shard, which is useful for Tapu Lele itself and teammates that aim for a sweep such as Hawlucha and Volcarona. Focus Blast lets Tapu Lele hit common Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn. Psyshock allows Tapu Lele to hit foes with weaker Defense stats like Assault Vest Tornadus-T and Volcarona, along with shutting down Calm Mind Tera Poison Cresselia. Future Sight can be used to hit in tandem with teammates such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, threatening Toxapex and Zapdos looking to switch into their attacks. Alternatively, Hidden Power Fire nails Mega Scizor along with hitting Ferrothorn more consistently than Focus Blast. Tera Psychic is the premier Tera option, as it boosts Tapu Lele's Psychic STAB attacks to ludicrous heights, smashing through most neutral targets such as Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Tapu Koko. Tera Fairy is a niche alternative, boosting Moonblast to powerful levels while minimizing the threat of Pursuit from Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Despite having Focus Blast, Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn are still effective checks to Tapu Lele, so teammates such as Gliscor and Mega Lopunny can be used to mitigate this. Hawlucha can both utilize Psychic Terrain to activate Unburden while helping break through Mega Scizor, allowing Tapu Lele to clean up with ease late-game.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Tapu Lele is one of the strongest wallbreakers in the tier, having no commonly used consistent defensive checks. Hidden Power Fire can OHKO most Mega Scizor and deal heavy damage to Ferrothorn without the chance of missing, unlike Focus Blast. Focus Blast hits Heatran and Ferrothorn and OHKOes Mega Tyranitar. Psyshock can hit Galarian Slowking, 2HKO Chansey, and OHKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T. Future Sight can help teammates like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny wallbreak, as it deals good damage to switch-ins like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Landorus-T. Late-game cleaners like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, Urshifu-R, and Bulk Up Great Tusk really appreciate Tapu Lele's ability to force damage onto would-be checks such as Corviknight and Heatran. However, Tapu Lele is very prediction reliant and can often invite in Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, Iron Crown, and Mega Scizor. Additionally, it struggles against common revenge killers such as Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Lopunny. Therefore, a strong defensive core is recommended when building around Tapu Lele to minimize the impact of these offensive threats, especially having a switch-in to the aforementioned Steel-types that may come in on a Psychic or Moonblast. Good switch-ins to these include Heatran and Alomomola, with the latter serving as a pivot with Flip Turn to safely get Tapu Lele on the field against passive foes like Toxapex and Gliscor.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Tapu Lele becomes a fearsome breaker after a single boost, threatening common defensive Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Mega Tyranitar. Focus Blast is useful coverage, hitting many defensive staples like Ferrothorn, Garganacl, and Heatran for super effective damage. Fightinium Z in tandem with Focus Blast allows Tapu Lele to reliably OHKO Ferrothorn and Heatran, and heavily damage Mega Scizor and Ting-Lu. Although Tapu Lele is a fearsome wallbreaker, it requires a Calm Mind boost to heavily damage the majority of the metagame, so Pokemon that can provide it a setup opportunity via pivoting such as Urshifu-R, Gliscor, and Alomomola are beneficial. Tapu Lele is also very prone to getting revenge killed by physical attackers that can bypass Tapu Lele's Special Defense boosts, such as Zamazenta, Kartana, and Weavile, so teammates such as Zapdos, Moltres, and Toxapex are appreciated.

Swords Dance.description: Tapu Bulu sets itself apart from other Grass-types thanks to its high offensive capabilities, Terrain-boosted Horn Leech, good coverage in Close Combat and Stone Edge, and good defensive typing, checking Pokemon like Zamazenta, Urshifu-R and Rotom-W. It also provides Grassy Terrain for its team, giving passive recovery to teammates like Heatran and Toxapex, making them even harder to deal with. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Kingambit and Stone Edge threaten Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Dragonite while letting Tapu Bulu beat Volcarona. Rockium Z gives Tapu Bulu a strong nuke, allowing it to break through Zapdos more reliably while also OHKOing would-be checks like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y on the switch-in. Fightinium Z, on the other hand, helps it break through Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor and KOes Heatran after luring it in. Leftovers gives Tapu Bulu more passive recovery, allowing it to set up multiple times against more balanced teams. The given EV spread ensures Tapu Bulu outspeeds Magnezone and Mega Tyranitar while optimizing its bulk. Tera Water retains Tapu Bulu's utility against rain while making it resist Ice-types moves from Pokemon like Weavile and Fire-type moves from Heatran and Volcarona, while Tera Steel avoids Toxic, grants a helpful Flying resistance against the lieks of Tornadus-T and Zados, and synergizes well with Grassy Terrain, as it weakens Earthquake. Both options also let it resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo, allowing Tapu Bulu to win against it thanks to Horn Leech's recovery. Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its strong wallbreaking capability. Heatran checks Fire-types like Volcarona and Skeledirge, Flying-types like Tornadus-T, and appreciates Grassy Terrain weakening Earthquake. In return, Tapu Bulu can check Rotom-W and Urshifu-R, using them as setup fodder. Kartana synergizes well with Tapu Bulu, as Tapu Bulu can break through most of Kartana's checks thanks to Z-Moves and boosts its Leaf Blade with Grassy Terrain, letting Kartana clean with its Choice Scarf set. In the same vein, Mega Scizor works well with Tapu Bulu, as together they can overwhelm their common checks, like Zapdos and Heatran.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Fini compresses roles as speed control that provides valuable defensive utility and support. It can outspeed and revenge kill foes like Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, Garchomp, and Iron Valiant while using its typing and remarkable bulk to switch into Pokemon like Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R. Other than shutting down problematic setup sweepers like Volcarona, Trick + Taunt improves Tapu Fini's matchup against defensive Pokemon by crippling and shutting down switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Clodsire, and Toxapex, especially with Misty Terrain to protect it and its teammates against theirs and the likes of Rotom-W, Heatran, and Gastrodon's status moves. If the team lacks an entry hazard remover, Tapu Fini can run Defog if necessary, as it matches up well against entry hazard setters like Heatran, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. However, its vulnerability to all forms of entry hazards and lack of longevity make it a poor candidate to do it consistently. Ice Beam can be run to potentially 2HKO offensive Tornadus-T and OHKO Landorus-T, while Nature's Madness is an option to dent its checks hard—especially ones that lack reliable recovery—such as Ferrothorn, Galarian Slowking, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. However, forgoing Taunt or Defog loses out on Tapu Fini's utility, which makes shutting down walls and supporting its team needlessly more difficult. Tera Steel allows Tapu Fini to emergency check threats like Tapu Lele and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T; it also provides a better defensive typing against walls like Toxapex and Ferrothorn, which is more useful if using Taunt. The Speed EVs allow Tapu Fini to outspeed +1 Mega Gyarados, while the Special Attack EVs allow it to KO Urshifu-R after Stealth Rock. Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Ferrothorn are great teammates to deal with faster threats like boosted Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf users such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Landorus-T; Ferrothorn also provides Spikes to chip down foes like Ferrothorn, Garchomp, and Garganacl into Tapu Fini's KO range, compensating for its middling damage output. Offensive teammates like Volcarona, Kartana, and Weavile love its Misty Terrain to protect them against debilitating status from walls like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Skeledirge, letting them set up and attack more safely; Volcarona also enjoys Tapu Fini luring in and crippling their shared checks like Toxapex and Clodsire with Trick, while Choice Band Weavile appreciates Tapu Fini removing Stealth Rock with Defog.

Meteor Beam.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Wall.description: Buzzwole serves as a solid wall, as its typing lets it take on some of the most powerful attackers in the tier, such as Zamazenta, Kingambit, and Great Tusk. Ice Punch allows Buzzwole to threaten Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Clodsire, as well as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite. Bulk Up accumulates boosts alongside Pokemon such as Howl Zamazenta, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and defensive Mega Scizor, meaning they cannot overwhelm Buzzwole. Toxic is a niche alternative if Buzzwole's team wishes to play more proactively, as it cripples the likes of Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge that would otherwise take advantage of Buzzwole. Heavy-Duty Boots ignores entry hazards, letting Buzzwole consistently switch into the Pokemon it gets tasked to counter without being worn down. Tera Water gives Buzzwole a Water resistance, allowing it to wall Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Floatzel, and Barraskewda in rain. The given EV spread maximizes Buzzwole's physical bulk while ensuring it always outspeeds Kingambit. Buzzwole fits best on defensive teams, which appreciate it as a fallback measure against the myriad of physical wallbreakers while not caring for its relative passivity. Pokemon such as Clodsire and Hippowdon can shore up Buzzwole's weakness to common special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. Buzzwole appreciates pivots such as Toxapex, Tornadus-T, and Gliscor, which can absorb chip damage from moves like Scald, Salt Cure and—for the latter two—Knock Off. Buzzwole has a tendency to thud into Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele if not using Toxic, so it pairs well with the likes of Gholdengo and Weavile that can exploit them.

Defensive.description: 16 Defense EVs with a Relaxed Nature lets Celesteela live 2 Close Combats from Mega Lopunny from full.

Autotomize Sweeper.description: 196 Speed EVs outspeed Zamazenta after one Autotomize.

Paper Cut (Swords Dance).description: With its sky-high Attack stat further bolstered by Swords Dance, Kartana serves as a threatening setup sweeper. Sacred Sword hits foes such as Ferrothorn and Heatran, while Knock Off hits Galarian Slowking and Iron Crown as well as removes Heavy-Duty Boots from Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Giga Impact is used with Normalium Z to OHKO foes like Raging Bolt, Gouging Fire, and Zapdos after a Swords Dance. Fightinium Z allows unboosted Kartana to OHKO Heatran and Ferrothorn along with Mega Scizor, Mega Mawile, Corviknight, and Raging Bolt after a boost. Synthesis is an option to give Kartana longevity, allowing it to threaten to wallbreak multiple times per game. Grassium Z is another option for a strong STAB move once boosted, but it has less applications than the aforementioned items. A set with Protective Pads and Tera Dark can be used as well, but Kartana without a Z-Move is usually undesirable. Teammates like Iron Boulder and Gouging Fire appreciate Kartana's ability to force chip damage onto Pokemon like Landorus-T, letting them eventually power through these Pokemon late-game. Kartana is prone to getting revenge killed by offensive threats like Darkrai, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta; as such, bulky Pokemon like Galarian Slowking and Zamazenta can check the aforementioned threats and open pathways for Kartana to sweep. In return, Kartana can threaten Gliscor and Alomomola for its partners. Speed control options like Mega Lopunny and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele are also good teammates, as they can revenge kill Pokemon like Darkrai and Iron Valiant while also forming a strong offensive core with Kartana.

Paper Plane (Choice Scarf).description: Armed with a Choice Scarf, Kartana becomes a dangerous revenge killer and late-game cleaner thanks to its Attack stat and snowball potential with Beast Boost. Its great Speed tier lets it effectively outspeed many boosted threats such as Garchomp,Mega Gyarados, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele as well as getting the jump on naturally faster Pokemon such as Weavile, Darkrai, and Ogerpon-W, making it an effective Choice Scarf user. Knock Off lets Kartana remove items from defensive Pokemon such as Corviknight, Toxapex, and Skarmory, which makes them more susceptible to entry hazards from its teammates, and it also hits Galarian Slowking hard. Sacred Sword targets Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, and opposing Kartana. Smart Strike is Kartana's strongest Steel-type STAB attack for dealing with Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Dragonite. Defog can be used over Smart Strike to guarantee an emergency Defog for teammates like Mega Charizard-Y, which can be used when predicting a switch or while sacrificing Kartana. Tera Grass elevates Leaf Blade's power to incredible levels, which allows Kartana to snowball with greater ease against weakened teams. Tera Dark can be used instead to give Kartana STAB on Knock Off, which becomes extremely spammable against most netural targets. Kartana fits well on offensive teams, as wallbreakers like Urshifu-R, Garchomp, and Mega Medicham appreciate its ability to revenge kill Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Darkrai, and Ogerpon-W. Kartana struggles against Pokemon like Skarmory and Toxapex due to its inability to break through them, so allies such as Heatran and Tapu Lele can help beat them for Kartana. In return, Kartana can beat down bulky Water-types such as Alomomola for them. Heatran can also set up Stealth Rock for Kartana, which synergizes well with Knock Off's removal of Heavy-Duty Boots from Stealth Rock-weak Pokemon like Zapdos and Tornadus-T. Kartana also struggles to break through Mega Latias because of its bulk and ability to tank most of Kartana's attacks as well as Zapdos because of its typing and ability to OHKO Kartana with Hurricane. Thus, Pursuit support from the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Choice Band Weavile can help in this regard.

Paper Fan (Bulky Defog).description: Kartana serves as a good check to Pokemon like Garchomp, Mega Tyranitar, and Ogerpon-W lacking Superpower, while packing good utility with Defog. Its great matchup versus the former two, along with Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Ferrothorn exacerbate this, being particularly one of the most effective Defoggers in the metagame. With Grassium Z, Kartana is even more effective at removing entry hazards, being able to deal a massive blow to Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Gliscor, KOing even the latter two with minor chip. Knock Off is Kartana's coverage move of choice, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Volcarona while giving it an avenue to make meaningful progress against Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Galarian Slowking. The given EV spread lets Bloom Doom OHKO offensive Garchomp, which could otherwise comfortably tank Leaf Blade and KO Kartana with its +2 Earthquake. Due to Kartana's ability to often lure Ground-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Garchomp with its Bloom Doom, Tapu Koko makes for an excellent teammate, also appreciating Kartana's ability to keep Ferrothorn's entry hazards off the field; in return, Tapu Koko can check Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T for Kartana. Teammates that benefit from Kartana’s entry hazard removal like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y form a nice core with it as well, allowing them to stay healthy and hit the field to help break down Kartana’s checks like Zapdos and Heatran. Kartana is not without flaw as a Defogger; it is most notably helpless against Stealth Rock Heatran, so teammates that assist with Heatran such as Gliscor and Hisuian Samurott work well, being able to often trade entry hazards to help mitigate Kartana's inability to safely clear them in the face of Heatran. Furthermore, Kartana’s terrible Special Defense renders it unable to check Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko effectively unlike other Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran, so teammates like Galarian Slowking, Weavile, and Landorus-T can ease these matchups.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Rillaboom is a decent wallbreaker that can easily break through offensive teams and revenge kill offensive staples like Iron Valiant and Iron Boulder with its strong priority move in Grassy Glide. Wood Hammer is an even stronger STAB move, allowing Rillaboom to dispatch defensive stopgaps like Toxapex and Landorus-T; its recoil is also partially offset by Grassy Terrain recovery. Knock Off lets Rillaboom force progress on its rather limited defensive answers like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos by removing their Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots and making them more prone to being worn down by repeated hits or entry hazards, while Superpower shellacks supposed switch-ins like Heatran and Ferrothorn. U-turn lets Rillaboom pivot itself out from unfavorable matchups against the aforementioned Corviknight, as well as against Dragonite and Mega Scizor, letting it form a pivoting core with teammates like Urshifu-R or switch into threatening teammates like Volcarona and Heatran. Hawlucha in particular greatly benefits from being able to activate Unburden through Grassy Seed, giving it a Defense boost and letting it sweep weakened teams. In return, it threatens the Steel-types that wall Rillaboom, like Ferrothorn and Heatran. Dragon-types like Raging Bolt and Gouging Fire can be massive headaches for Rillaboom, so teammates that can threaten them, like Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele, are great partners for Rillaboom. On the flip side, teammates like Gouging Fire and Mega Scizor can struggle to break through bulky Water-types like Rotom-W and Toxapex, a job well-suited for Rillaboom. In return, those teammates appreciate Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain halving the power of miscellaneous uses of Earthquake, while they break through troublesome Steel- and Poison-types like Heatran and Galarian Slowking.

Swords Dance.description:
188 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested Heatran.

The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Bulky Pivot.description: Cinderace is a good bulky pivot thanks to its high Speed, good Attack, and utility options in Will-O-Wisp and Court Change. These traits along with its typing let Cinderace act as a soft check to Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Kartana, and Mega Scizor, which is useful on offense and bulky offense teams. Will-O-Wisp cripples physically offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Mega Mawile. Court Change helps temporarily keep off entry hazards, especially from the likes of Ferrothorn, while High Jump Kick OHKOes Mega Tyranitar and deals heavy damage to Heatran and Mega Diancie. The given EV spread allows Cinderace to outspeed Iron Valiant and 2HKO maximum HP Galarian Slowking with Pyro Ball. Tera Fire bolsters Pyro Ball's damage, letting it OHKO offensive Volcarona and 2HKO Gliscor after Stealth Rock. Cinderace can form a VoltTurn core with other pivots like Tapu Koko and Meowscarada, as they can take advantage of its checks like Toxapex, Alomomola, and Rotom-W. In return, Cinderace can pivot in to help deal with their checks like Ferrothorn and Heatran. Cinderace struggles to damage defensive Pokemon like Zapdos, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk, making offensive teammates like Iron Boulder, Meowscarada, and Urshifu-R good options to help weaken or outright OHKO them. Teammates like Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko can benefit from Cinderace's ability to often burn Ground-types like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Garchomp, making it much easier to chip them down while reducing the power of their Ground-type STAB.

Defensive Pivot.description: Corviknight uses its favorful defensive typing, pivoting capabilities, and good matchups against entry hazard setters like Gliscor and Landorus-T to become a good defensive glue for teams that lack strong checks to powerful wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Weavile while also being able to consistently remove hazards and gain momentum for its team. Brave Bird allows Corviknight to not be completely useless against Pokemon like Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Ogerpon-W. Body Press hits Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Ferrothorn for meaningful damage, preventing them from consistently getting hazards up against Corviknight. U-turn is a vital tool, allowing Corviknight to preserve momentum against Pokemon that counter it, such as Raging Bolt and Heatran. Iron Defense can be used over Defog if a team already has hazard removal, and it allows Corviknight to boost alongside Pokemon that could otherwise set up on it like Mega Mawile and Mega Scizor while also boosting the damage output of Body Press to monstrous levels. Iron Defense can also be used over U-turn on stall teams that don’t mind the momentum sink and appreciate Corviknight compressing multiple roles, such as being a check to Mega Gyarados, Mega Mawile, and Tapu Lele; as a Defogger; and as a good wincon. Rocky Helmet is used to punish contact moves from Weavile, Urshifu-R, Landorus-T, and Rillaboom, but Leftovers or Covert Cloak can be used for passive healing or ignoring secondary effects from moves like Tapu Lele’s Psychic and Toxapex’s Scald. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Corviknight to pivot more safely without fearing chip damage from Stealth Rock and more reliably switch in and remove hazards with Defog. Tera Dragon allows Corviknight to gain resistances to Fire- and Electric-type attacks from Mega Charizard Y and Zapdos while also allowing it to check Ogerpon-W and rain sweepers like Barraskewda and Mega Swampert. The first EV spread allows Corviknight to survive a Swords Dance-boosted Continental Crush from Landorus-T, with the remaining EVs dumped into Special Defense to let Corviknight take on Tapu Lele and Mega Latios a bit better. The second EV spread should be used on Iron Defense variants to outspeed uninvested Heatran. Corviknight mainly fits on balance teams, where Pokemon like Toxapex and Mega Tyranitar appreciate its ability to switch into devastating wallbreakers like the aforementioned Tapu Lele, Garchomp, and Rillaboom. Wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Weavile appreciate Corviknight pivoting them in safely against Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Garchomp because of their frailty. A good defensive backbone that can check Pokemon that threaten Corviknight offensively like Volcarona, Heatran, and Raging Bolt is much appreciated, usually consisting of teammates like Gliscor and Toxapex. Corviknight can also fit on stall teams, which contain teammates like Clodsire and Dondozo that help check Tapu Koko and Gouging Fire are found.

Bulk Up + Substitute.description: Substitute + Bulk Up Corviknight is a formidable wincon on balance teams, utilizing its elite bulk in combination with Pressure to PP stall would-be checks like Heatran, Zapdos, and Toxapex while still being a consistent check to Tapu Lele and Calm Mind Iron Valiant. Bulk Up is important for Corviknight to attempt a sweep in the later stages of the game as well as still be a functional check to the likes of Mega Scizor and Swords Dance Gliscor. Substitute lets Corviknight rack up boosts safely on more passive Pokemon like Clefable, Toxapex, and Galarian Slowking; it also prevents it from having its Leftovers removed from Knock Off and avoid status while also letting it waste more PP from Heatran's and Zapdos’s attacks. Tera Dragon is extremely important for Corviknight, as it lets it flip the matchup on Fire- and Electric-types like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Rotom-W, turning the latter two into setup fodder. The given EV spread allows Corviknight to live a boosted Continental Crush from Garchomp and outspeed uninvested Mega Scizor, with the rest maximizing its special bulk. Entry hazard support is crucial for Corviknight to sweep, as it needs to waste as much recovery PP as it can from its checks to sweep in the later stages of the game, making Clefable and Gliscor important teammates. Both of these also switch into Toxapex safely, while the latter can also pivot and take advantage of Heatran. Knock Off support further supplements Corviknight by crippling Zapdos, Toxapex, and Rotom-W, making Mega Tyranitar and Weavile good partners. Corviknight can often be worn down easily and forced to waste Roost PP early on if it is the sole defensive pivot, making it inefficient at sweeping, so pairing it up with a sturdy defensive backbone, for example Toxapex + Mega Latias, can help spread the load. Prior to Terastallizing, Corviknight can be forced out by strong Electric- and Fire-types like Tapu Koko, Heatran, and Raging Bolt, so having strong checks to these Pokemon such as the aforementioned Gliscor, Ting-Lu, and Draco Meteor Mega Latias is important.

Rain Wallbreaker.description: Choice Band Barraskewda serves as one of the best wallbreakers on rain teams due to its high Attack and Speed in conjunction with its rain- and Tera-boosted Water-type attacks. With Swift Swim, Barraskewda outspeeds nearly the entire metagame, including boosted foes like Iron Valiant, Iron Boulder, and Hawlucha. Liquidation's chance to drop Defense potentially lets Barraskewda beat Pokemon it normally can't on the switch in like Latias and Rotom-W. Aqua Jet allows it to finish off dangerous foes outside of rain like Volcarona and Iron Boulder. Flip Turn allows Barraskewda to pivot out on Pokemon like Toxapex and Dondozo while also chipping them and giving a free switch to its teammates like Mega Swampert. Close Combat KOes Ferrothorn and Archaludon after Stealth Rock and can chip Ogerpon-W on the switch. Psychic Fangs is a niche move that allows it to beat Pokemon that it would otherwise struggle against like Toxapex, but it doesn't do much else. Tera Water allows Barraskewda to significantly dent checks like Mega Latias and Rotom-W, as well as potentially breaking Toxapex after Defense drops. Pelipper is necessary teammate to set up rain, remove entry hazards, or pivot out with U-turn and let Barraskewda in safely due to its extreme frailty. Mega Swampert is an important teammate thanks to its immunity to Electric-type attacks from Raging Bolt and Rotom-W; it also threatens Toxapex and can wear down foes like Rotom-W and Ferrothorn so Barraskewda has an easier time muscling past them. Barraskewda is easily revenge killed by Rillaboom and Raging Bolt so defensive teammates like Iron Treads and Ferrothorn are necessary; they can also set up hazards that will wear down Barraskewda's checks like Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Iron Treads in particular is a good partner because it pivots in Barraskewda with Volt Switch and removes hazards so Barraskewda can break through teams more often. In return, Barraskewda forces out Fighting- and Fire-types that check Iron Treads and Ferrothorn such as Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Volcarona. While it has a great Attack stat, Barraskewda struggles to beat defensive foes that resist Water-type attacks like Dondozo, Alomomola, Dragonite, and Tera Dragon Zapdos, so Archaludon is a good partner to threaten these foes. In return, Barraskewda threatens Ground- and Fire-types that check Archaludon such as Gliscor, Ting-Lu, and Volcarona.

Shell Smash.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Eject Button Support.description: Hatterene's access to Magic Bounce, a vast support movepool, and Eject Button gives it a key role on offense teams as a pivot and a way to prevent entry hazards. Healing Wish gives Hatterene the ability to fully heal one of its teammates, giving wallbreakers and setup Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y and Kingambit another chance to break through the opposing team. Mystical Fire is generally preferred over Dazzling Gleam to hit Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Kingambit on the switch, but Dazzling Gleam can be used to threaten Dragonite, Garchomp, and Dragapult. Nuzzle provides Hatterene with a way to punish Pokemon that would safely pivot into it otherwise, such as Heatran and Tornadus-T. Eject Button gives Hatterene the ability to take a hit and pivot into a teammate, letting frail wallbreakers such as Mega Charizard Y and Weavile come onto the field. Tera Steel removes Hatterene's weaknesses to Ghost and Steel, letting it pass a Healing Wish or cripple an opposing Pokemon such as Dragapult and Gholdengo while retaining its advantage against Dragon-types, though typically you would want to Terastallize a teammate for more offensive pressure. The given EV spread lets Hatterene outspeed Garganacl and Toxapex while maximizing its ability to pivot into physical attacks. Hatterene greatly benefits teams that rely on keeping entry hazards off the field, such as sun teams and some offense teams. As such, Mega Charizard Y is a fantastic partner, as it appreciates Hatterene keeping Stealth Rock off the field and walling Toxapex; in return, it is able to pressure Pokemon Hatterene brings in, such as Gholdengo and Kingambit. Focus Sash users such as Polteageist and Cloyster also make for good teammates thanks to Hatterene's ability to keep off hazards. Similarly, pivots such as Tapu Lele and Dragapult appreciate Hatterene's ability to keep off hazards and give them a second chance with Healing Wish, letting them come in safely and consistently. Hatterene's lack of longevity means that it usually cannot act as the sole form of hazard control. As such, Rapid Spin Great Tusk is a good partner alongside Hatterene for keeping hazards off of the field while also being able to support Mega Charizard Y on sun teams.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Hatterene is a solid option for balance teams looking for both entry hazard control and a late-game wincon. Magic Bounce gives Hatterene a way to switch into entry hazard setters, utilize Calm Mind to force them out, and avoid status from Pokemon such as Garchomp and Toxapex. Psyshock lets Hatterene beat opposing Calm Mind and Quiver Dance sweepers like Iron Valiant and Volcarona, while Stored Power lets it bypass Skeledirge with enough Calm Mind boosts. Mystical Fire hits Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Ferrothorn super effectively. Draining Kiss acts as a form of recovery for Hatterene. Tera Water gives Hatterene a solid defensive typing while removing its weakness to Steel-type attacks from the likes of Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. The given EV spread lets Hatterene outspeed Garganacl and Toxapex, letting Hatterene take out Toxapex with an attack before having its boosts removed by Haze. Hatterene works well when paired with Pokemon that dislike entry hazards, such as defensive Pokemon without Heavy-Duty Boots. These include partners like Toxapex and Garganacl, which can check other offensive and defensive Pokemon, giving Hatterene the leeway for a late-game sweep. Flyinium Z Tornadus-T appreciates Hatterene being able to Terastallize to force opposing Gholdengo to Terastallize, as well as keeping hazards off the field for it. Kingambit and Garganacl are great partners for their ability to reliably check Ghost-types like Dragapult and Gholdengo, with Kingambit even being able to Pursuit trap them. Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor can check Kingambit for Hatterene as well. Hatterene's lack of longevity outside of Draining Kiss means that it appreciates a secondary form of entry hazard removal from teammates such as Tornadus-T, Zapdos, Great Tusk, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Hatterene enjoys pairing up with Spikes users such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory, as they pressure the opponent into using Defog, alleviating Hatterene's need to block entry hazards, as well as wearing down Hatterene's answers such as Heatran and Gholdengo.

Dual Screens.description: Grimmsnarl serves as the premier dual screens setter on hyper offense teams due to its ability Prankster and access to Taunt, which crucially denies entry hazards from many common leads, as well as blocking opposing attempts to use Taunt or remove dual screens with Defog. Foul Play requires no Attack EVs to function, allowing Grimmsnarl to OHKO several Attack-boosting Pokemon that try to set up on it such as Ogerpon-W and offensive Garchomp. Parting Shot is sometimes used to pivot and force out Mega Diancie, while Thunder Wave is also an option to cripple fast threats. Tera Steel allows Grimmsnarl to resist Fairy attacks from Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant, although using Tera on it is typically not ideal. 140 Special Defense EVs let Grimmsnarl survive two Moonblasts from Choice Scarf Tapu Lele behind Light Screen while the rest of its EVs are dumped into Defense, as most priority moves from Pokemon that can outspeed its Prankster dual screens are physical, such as Fake Out from Mega Lopunny and Mega Medicham, with Mega Medicham occasionally using Bullet Punch as well. Teammates that benefit from Grimmsnarl's utility are mainly setup sweepers that can blow through most teams if allowed multiple turns of setup, such as Iron Crown, Mega Gyarados, Gouging Fire, Volcarona, and Dragonite, and hard hitting wallbreakers such as Ursaluna, and Mega Mawile that can beat almost anything one-on-one with dual screens up. Strong Fairy-type attackers such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele can often leave Grimmsnarl severely chipped despite Light Screen, hurting its ability to set dual screens later on in the game. Additionally, entry hazard setters who ignore Taunt such as Mega Diancie and Mega Tyranitar give Grimmsnarl and the hyper offense teams it is found on trouble. Teammates like Iron Crown and Mega Mawile can turn these offensive Fairy-types into setup fodder, while teammates such as Urshifu-R can turn Mega Tyranitar and other Dark-types, like Weavile and Hisuian Samurott capable of ignoring Prankster into setup fodder.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Urshifu-R becomes a powerful wallbreaker after a single boost, threatening common metagame threats like Gliscor, Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Heatran with its power and coverage. Surging Strikes even has the additional merit of bypassing Defense boosts from the likes of Zamazenta, Garganacl, and Great Tusk. Trailblaze is the recommended move for the last slot as it allows Urshifu-R to avoid revenge killing from naturally fast Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Thunder Punch is an alternative that threatens Pokemon like Toxapex, Slowbro, and Alomomola. Tera Steel is advised for preventing revenge killing from the likes of Tornadus-T, Iron Valiant, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, while granting a Toxic immunity allowing it to use Alomomola as setup fodder. If using Thunder Punch, however, Tera Electric is recommended to meaningfully threaten Toxapex and Slowbro notably letting Urshifu-R OHKO Toxapex with Tera Electric Thunder Punch after a boost. Protective Pads is recommended to ignore problematic abilities like Rough Skin, Iron Barbs, Static, and Flame Body, from Pokemon like Garchomp, Ferrothorn, Zapdos, and Moltres. Urshifu-R has a hard time sweeping without Trailblaze, so defensive options to fall back on like Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, Garganacl, and Zapdos are appreciated. Variants without Thunder Punch struggle against common Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo, so special wallbreakers that can force them out such as Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko are good teammates.

Choice Band.description: Urshifu-R's decent Speed tier, powerful STAB combination, and Choice Band allow it to break past common bulky Pokemon like Landorus-T, Galarian Slowking, and Ferrothorn. U-turn allows Urshifu-R to maintain momentum against Pokemon that it would usually struggle to deal meaningful damage against such as Slowbro and Mega Latias. Aqua Jet allows Urshifu-R to revenge kill faster Pokemon such as chipped Mega Diancie and Volcarona. Thunder Punch can deal considerable damage to the likes of Toxapex and Slowbro. Urshifu-R makes use of Tera Water to deal massive damage with Surging Strikes and force its typical checks like Iron Defense Zamazenta and Galarian Slowking to switch out. It appreciates teammates like Galarian Slowking due to its ability to set Future Sight to break past Toxapex and Alomomola and Mega Scizor, which can also cover Urshifu-R's bad matchup against Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Both Galarian Slowking and Mega Scizor are able to pivot, bringing Urshifu-R in safely against Pokemon such as Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. Water-types such as Slowbro, Alomomola, and Toxapex are roadblocks for Urshifu-R, so partners that threaten them like Tapu Koko and Raging Bolt are appreciated. Tapu Koko can also boost the damage of Urshifu-R's Thunder Punch with Electric Terrain. Zapdos is able to hinder Urshifu-R with Static, making Mega Diancie, Kyurem, and Iron Valiant valuable options for teammates with their shared ability to threaten Zapdos. Urshifu-R is also threatened by faster offensive Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, which makes bulkier Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Galarian Slowking, and Gliscor excellent partners.

Choice Scarf.description: With the Speed boost from Choice Scarf, Urshifu-R is one of the strongest pivots and cleaners in the metagame. It can outspeed many common threats like Mega Lopunny, Greninja, Ogerpon-W, Mega Diancie, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele while also being able to revenge kill many setup sweepers even after a boost, such as Mega Gyarados and Gouging Fire. Addtionally, Surging Strikes allows Urshifu-R to OHKO Focus Sash users like Glimmora and Landorus-T while also improving its matchup against Zamazenta, bypassing its Dauntless Shield Defense boost. U-turn provides Urshifu-R the utility to gain momentum from its checks like Alomomola, Slowbro, Toxapex, and Corviknight. Aqua Jet can serve as a backup plan to revenge kill faster setup sweepers like Volcarona, while Thunder Punch can hit bulky Water-types like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Slowbro as well as Corviknight. Tera Water enables Urshifu-R to achieve valuable OHKOes versus the likes of Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, and Mega Lopunny, while also strengthening Aqua Jet to better combat setup sweepers like Iron Boulder. Teammates like Raging Bolt and Tapu Lele appreciate Urshifu-R's ability to bring them in against bulky defensive walls like Corviknight, Alomomola, and Toxapex. Tapu Lele can also set strong Future Sight for Urshifu-R to abuse and break through Toxapex. However, it is recommended to not to use Aqua Jet when Urshifu-R is paired with Tapu Lele due to its Psychic Surge. Abilities like Rough Skin, Static, and Flame Body as well as Rocky Helmet punish Choice Scarf Urshifu-R due to the multi-hit nature of Surging Strikes, so teammates with access to Knock Off like Landorus-T and Tornadus-T are useful to help Urshifu-R by removing Rocky Helmet from the aforementioned foes as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Zapdos and Moltres.

Bulk Up.description:
140 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested Corviknight.

The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Enamorus is a potent wallbreaker, utilizing its strong Moonblast alongside colorful coverage to punch severe holes into defensive cores. Earth Power and Mystical Fire complement its STAB Moonblast well, with the former hitting Toxapex, Clodsire, Gholdengo, and Heatran, while the latter OHKOes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. Focus Blast grants Enamorus its strongest attack to hit Garganacl and Mega Tyranitar, which could otherwise survive Earth Power and Moonblast, respectively, while Psychic provides a safer middle ground option for Toxapex Clodsire, and Mega Venusaur, which staves off its attacks otherwise. Tera Fairy grants Enamorus a power boost to Moonblast, notably allowing it to secure OHKOs against the likes of Landorus-T and Rotom-W, which would barely survive it otherwise. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate its wallbreaking power while being able to support it adequately. Pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, and Tornadus-T grant Enamorus free switch in opportunities against Great Tusk, opposing Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. The latter two pivots and Great Tusk, also provide entry hazard removal, which aids Enamorus given its Stealth Rock weakness. Enamorus works well with fast cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana, as they appreciate Enamorus punching holes into the likes of Gholdengo and Mega Scizor for the latter two to clean up weakened defensive cores.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Enamorus serve as a solid wallbreaker, using forced switches from the likes of Great Tusk and Garchomp to set up. It is incredibly difficult to switch into after a boost given its strong Moonblast alongside coverage options in Earth Power and Mystical Fire to hit Fairy-resistant foes such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn, respectively. Alternatively, Enamorus can forgo Mystical Fire for Substitute to take advantage of pivoting attempts as well as sponge attacks from revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Iron Valiant, although it makes it less effective at hitting Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. If using Substitute, Enamorus can opt for Leftovers instead of the standard Heavy-Duty Boots to potentially set up more Substitutes. Tera Ground boosts the power of Earth Power, allowing it to KO most Toxapex and Gholdengo sets after a boost, as well as giving it an immunity to Tapu Koko and Rotom-W's Electric-type attacks. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that appreciate its use as an early- to mid-game wallbreaker while granting it sufficient opportunities to enter the field. Therefore, pivots such as Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T pair well with it, bringing Enamorus in on physical walls it can exploit such as Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Skarmory. Additionally, Pursuit trappers such as Mega Tyranitar and Weavile eliminate special walls such as Clodsire and Gholdengo that can serve as a roadblock to Enamorus. Fast late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana appreciate Enamorus, as they capitalize on it weakening or removing Steel-types for them to clean up.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Enamorus functions as an interesting revenge killer, being able to KO a range of setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Mega Gyarados, Baxcalibur, and even a weakened Volcarona courtesy of its great speed tier. Additionally, it can serve as a late-game cleaner once its checks such as Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Assault Vest Tornadus-T have been weakened by its teammates. However, its Stealth Rock weakness and relative frailty mean Enamorus struggles to withstand repeated switches as well as priority moves from the likes of Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny. Tera Fairy boosts the power of Moonblast, notably allowing it to 2HKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Aside from coverage to hit Steel-types in Mystical Fire and Earth Power, Healing Wish can bring back a weakened teammate in a pinch, potentially being able to change the tide of a game. Therefore, Enamorus fits best on offense teams that appreciate its utility in Healing Wish while providing a positive matchup against opposing offensive teams. Powerful wallbreakers such as Baxcalibur and Volcarona appreciate Enamorus's Healing Wish, giving them a second lease on life, while Enamorus in turn capitalizes on them weakening the likes of Toxapex and Mega Scizor to clean late-game. Enamorus also greatly enjoys entry hazard removal support from Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, or Great Tusk, as it minimalizes its Stealth Rock weakness so it can switch in more effectively mid-game. Enamorus struggles with special wall such as Clodsire and Gholdengo, so Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk make for good partners that can take advantage of them.

Offensive Pivot.description: Meowscarada is a powerful offensive pivot that utilizes its good Attack, high Speed, and great coverage to support teammates like Landorus-T. Triple Axel helps against Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T, and it can OHKO Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. Toxic Spikes, when paired with Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Landorus-T that pressure Toxic Spikes absorbers such as Toxapex and Galarian Slowking, can be hard to deal with and put setup sweepers like Iron Boulder on a timer. Spikes can be used to chip down foes like Ferrothorn and Toxapex after they have had their Heavy-Duty Boots removed. U-turn pivots out Meowscarda from its checks like Toxapex and Ferrothorn and brings in wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta against them. Protective Pads protects Meowscarada from the abilities of Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos and Rocky Helmet Pokemon like on Landorus-T, while Heavy-Duty Boots lets it avoid getting worn down by entry hazards. Tera Grass can help Meowscarada survive moves like Moonblast from Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Aqua Jet from Urshifu-R, if Protean has changed its type. Entry hazard setters like Garganacl, Landorus-T, and Gliscor appreciate having Meowscarada as a teammate, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Toxapex and Zapdos, making their hazards more potent. Meowscarada's mediocre defenses and weaknesses to Fighting-, Fire-, and Flying-type attacks mean it appreciates defensive teammates like Clefable, Alomomola, and Ferrothorn that resist or are neutral to those attacks. Meowscarada can pair well with other pivots like Landrous-T and Iron Crown, forming a VoltTurn core to help it deal with its checks like Toxapex. Meowscarada also pairs well with wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, which can help break through checks like Ferrothorn.

Defensive.description: With its good bulk, unique typing, and Unaware, Skeledirge has a decent niche as a defensive wall that can deny setup. Torch Song is a fantastic signature move that turns Skeledirge into a potent wincon. Torch Song also bypasses Substitute, punishing users of the move like Serperior, Kyurem, and Zamazenta. Will-O-Wisp lets Skeledirge hinder physical atackers like Zamazenta, Dragonite, and Mega Lopunny. Slack Off is required in order to take on the Pokemon it can check reliably. Hex is a strong STAB move that pairs well alongside Will-O-Wisp. Hex is also great when paired with Pokemon that have an easy time spreading status like Clefable and Toxapex, and it hits Gliscor for huge damage as well. Earth Power lets Skeledirge punish Heatran predicting a Torch Song or Will-O-Wisp while also hitting Gouging Fire, Mega Tyranitar, and Garganacl much harder. Specially defensive Skeledirge is a well-rounded tank, capable of taking on Volcarona, Iron Valiant lacking Shadow Ball, and Iron Crown. Physically defensive Skeledirge focuses purely on its physical walling capabilities, most notably against the likes of Zamazenta, Dragonite, physical variants of Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Tera Fairy provides an appreciated resistance to Dark and Immunity to Dragon, allowing specially defensive variants to handle the likes of Darkrai and Raging Bolt, while physically defensive variants are able to beat Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Tera Water lets Skeledirge play more effectively against rain sweepers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda and hinder them with Will-O-Wisp. It can also tackle Urshifu-R and Hisuian Samurott, all while having a great defensive typing in Water. Skeledirge is a good pick for certain balance and stall teams that appreciate its unique traits. Due to its vulnerability to Knock Off, Skeledirge really appreciates Pokemon that can absorb the move for it, so Pokemon like Gliscor, Clefable, and Mega Tyranitar are solid partners for it. Pokemon that resist Water like Toxapex and Alomomola are welcomed editions, and the latter appreciates Skeledirge's ability to handle Grass-types. Checks to Darkrai and Weavile like Mega Tyranitar and Zamazenta also help Skeledirge greatly, and in return, it's able to beat some of their answers, such as opposing Zamazenta and Clefable. Mega Lopunny in particular synergizes greatly with Skeledirge; it provides solid speed control and can switch into Knock Off, while Skeledirge provides a burn immunity and serves as a defensive backbone, which helps against the likes of Zamazenta and Mega Scizor that Mega Lopunny can otherwise struggle with.

IronPress.description: IronPress Garganacl functions as both a defensive stopgap to important threats like Heatran, Gouging Fire, and Volcarona and a potent setup sweeper with Iron Defense coupled with its sky high defensive stats. Unfortunately, it is extremely reliant on Tera to be a consistent check to the aforementioned Pokemon due to its pure Rock typing being a liability defensively. Iron Defense allows Garganacl to outscale other physical setup sweepers like Dragonite, Gouging Fire, and Gliscor and beat them. Body Press turns into a powerful move after a few Iron Defenses, letting Garganacl be immediately threatening and pressuring opponents who try to stall out Salt Cure via dual Regenerator or Poison Heal Pokemon. Salt Cure is a mainstay on Garganacl, letting it make consistent progress against almost every Pokemon in the tier, especially pressuring Toxapex, which threatens to take away its boosts with Haze, and Dondonzo and Skeledirge, which ignore its boosted Body Press. Leftovers is crucial on Garganacl to prevent it from being worn down by chip damage and allow it to use its Recovers sparingly. Garganacl is extremely reliant on Terastallization, and every Tera option changes what it is able and unable to check. Tera Fairy is an all-around stellar Tera type defensively, giving Garganacl only two uncommon weaknesses and flipping the script on Fighting-types like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta. Tera Water allows Garganacl to perform exceptionally against rain, walling Barraskewda, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R while still being an overall solid defensive Tera type. Tera Dragon lets Garganacl keep the Water and Fire resistances that Tera Water provides while also making it resist Grass, letting it wall Ogerpon-W. However, being weak to Fairy means Garganacl can be easily forced out by Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Iron Defense Garganacl fits best on bulkier teams that appreciate its unique defensive profile and the potential for it to be a wincon. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Clefable, and Gliscor is crucial for putting more pressure on the Pokemon that try to dance around Garganacl's Salt Cure. In order to not be too reliant on Tera, additional defensive pieces surrounding Garganacl are important, making options like Toxapex and Mega Latias great partners. These teammates also deal with the Fighting- and Ground-type Pokemon that pressure Garganacl. Lastly, Leftovers is important for Garganacl to function as a setup sweeper, so Knock Off absorbers like the aforementioned Toxapex and Mega Scizor are needed. Partners like Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Urshifu-R that appreciate Garganacl pressuring Steel-, Flying-, and Water-types like Ferrothorn and Toxapex also work well with it.

Stealth Rock.description: Garganacl is a practical Stealth Rock setter due to its high bulk, amazing ability, and access to Salt Cure. Garganacl can safely set up Stealth Rock against common pivots like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and Galarian Slowking. Common Defog users like Zapdos, Corviknight, and Moltres can barely threaten Garganacl and take dangerous passive damage from Salt Cure. Other entry hazard removal Pokemon like Landorus-T and Great Tusk also dislike Salt Cure as they rely on Leftovers for passive recovery. Protect is crucial for Garganacl for passive recovery from Leftovers and to exacerbate chip damage from Salt Cure. It can also help to scout moves from Choice item users like Tapu Lele and Rillaboom, as well as stalling weather turns against rain and sun teams. However, it is important not to rely on Protect too much to the point where Garganacl can be exploited by opponents. Garganacl has a variety of good Tera types; Tera Water turns the tables versus Pokemon like Urshifu-Rapid-Strike and Mega Scizor and performs better against rain and sun, but leaves it vulernable to opposing Garganacl and Electric-types like Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko. Tera Dragon has most of the advantages of Tera Water in addition to checking Ogerpon-W and Mega Charizard Y, but it makes Garganacl weak to Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Tera Fairy and Tera Ghost both help Garganacl to check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny. Teammates like Ogerpon-W and Mega Lopunny appreciate Garganacl's ability to threaten Water- and Flying-types. Garganacl also benefits from them dealing with offensive targets like Tapu Lele and opposing Ogerpon-W. Garganacl's main way to gain momentum is via Salt Cure, so foes with Abilities like Regenerator and Poison Heal can nullify its chip damage. It is therefore very helpful to have teammates like Weavile, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Koko to spam Knock Off or threaten common Regenerator pivots.

Curse.description: Curse Garganacl is a solid wincon that can turn games around in the blink of an eye. Curse in conjunction with Terastallization lets it take hits from common physical attackers like Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, and its ability prevents it from getting Toxic poisoned, a major roadblock to slow setup sweepers. Salt Cure allows Garganacl to chip foes and is complemented by Attack boosts from Curse; it also discourages common threats to Garganacl like Iron Crown and Urshifu-R from switching in directly. Earthquake hits almost all foes for decent damage with enough boosts, threatening Steel- and Electric-types like Iron Crown, Raging Bolt, Galarian Slowking, and Tapu Koko for particularly high damage; Salt Cure covers Flying-types that Earthquake cannot reach. Heavy Slam deals immediate damage to Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Clefable, which threaten to deal massive damage with their STAB moves or are immune to Salt Cure's passive damage in the latter's case. Tera Water allows Garganacl to beat common Water-types like Manaphy, Urshifu-R, and Mega Swampert, giving its team a positive matchup against rain teams. Tera Fairy allows Garganacl to resist Fighting-type moves from Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, especially when unboosted, as Garganacl gets several free turns to set up after surprising these foes. Garganacl is a fat momentum sapper that lends itself well to balance teams, as they are able to compensate for its lack of immediate power with their ability to withstand heavy damage; Alomomola, a commonly seen Pokemon on these archetypes, is a great ally that can heal up Garganacl, allowing it to be used more recklessly with Salt Cure to offset the passivity of other allies. Garganacl is extremely hampered by Taunt and Knock Off users, as they prevent it from setting up and healing and prevent Leftovers passive recovery. It is best to wait for such foes to be eliminated before trying to set up. Therefore, Knock Off absorbers like Mega Scizor and Gliscor are good teammates to threaten Knock Off users including Hisuian Samurott and Ferrothorn. Garganacl performs best when used with Terastallization, as its base typing gives it nasty weaknesses to common foes like Zamazenta and Landorus-T; thus, allies should try not to expend Terastallization early-game. This means that a solid defensive core, such as Alomomola and Heatran, should be used to help with the longevity of the team and can chip down foes until it is safe to set up.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Ceruledge is a massively threatening wallbreaker that fits well on hyper-offensive teams due to its ability to threaten common defensive pieces, like Galarian Slowking and Ferrothorn, while being able to take on offensive threats such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant thanks to its typing. Close Combat is a good coverage option, letting Ceruledge dent bulky Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar; alternatively, Shadow Sneak offers a form of priority that can pick off unsuspecting revenge killers like Iron Boulder. Focus Sash allows Ceruledge to usually guarantee an oppotunity to set up one Swords Dance, while Ghostium Z turns Poltergeist into a nuke that can eviscerate even the bulkiest of Pokemon, OHKOing even Alomomola and Toxapex at +2. Tera Ghost allows Poltergeist to be boosted to ludicrous power levels without having to invest in Ghostium Z, letting Ceruledge OHKO offensive Great Tusk and Gliscor after a boost. Bulky Dark-types, like the aforementioned Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar, can force Ceruledge out - therefore, Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta as well as Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant are great partners for it. In return, all of them appreciate Ceruledge being able to threaten bulky Pokemon that might try to take their attacks, such as Galarian Slowking, Alomomola, Toxapex, and Heatran. Revenge killers like Choice Scarf Urshifu-R and Samurott-H also limit Ceruledge's ability to impact the game beyond potentially grabbing one KO, so teammates that can deal with them, such as Mega Scizor and Dragonite, are highly appreciated. Water-types like the aforementioned Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W are also effective teammates for Ceruledge, as they can come in on Water-type attacks from opposing Urshifu-R and Samurott-H while being able to rely on Ceruledge to break through troublesome Grass-types like Ferrothorn.

Wall.description: With massive physical bulk, the superb ability of Unaware, and a solid defensive typing, Dondozo functions as a sturdy wall to many of the physical threats roaming the tier. While it prefers Liquidation, Waterfall is a good alternative, trading power and a potential Defense drop for greater PP, allowing Dondozo to continually chip away at threats during longer games. Curse turns Dondozo into an intimidating win condition in the later stages of the game, able to set up on the likes of Mega Mawile and Gouging Fire, while Body Press allows Dondozo to hit Water-resistant foes like Ferrothorn and Ogerpon-W. Tera Dragon flips the matchup on Pokemon which would normally threaten it, such as Kartana, Rillaboom, and especially Ogerpon-W. Due to its passive nature, Dondozo is found mainly on bulky teams, partnering well with Pokemon like Gliscor and Ting-Lu, which can handle Dondozo checks like Toxapex, Mega Latios, and Mega Latias, while Dondozo can check the Water-types that would threaten them, like Urshifu-R or Hisuian Samurott. Dondozo usually carries Heavy-Duty Boots as its item to ensure it can switch in safely when it is used on teams with less reliable entry hazard removal, though if paired with a reliable hazard remover like Tornadus-T, Dondozo can opt for Leftovers to shore up its poor recovery, allowing it to 1v1 threats such as Mega Scizor and Zamazenta more reliably.

Unaware Wall.description: Clodsire serves as a fantastic special wall, able to take on powerful attackers such as Dragapult and Mega Diancie while simultaneously stopping setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Volcarona. Spikes are preferred on Clodsire, as the move has more limited distribution and Clodsire enters the field commonly enough to have the opportunity to use the move. However, Stealth Rock can be used if Clodsire's team requires it. Toxic is used to cripple common switch-ins to Clodsire, such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Great Tusk. Poison Jab can be used to poison post-Tera Gholdengo attempting to remove its Ground weakness, and it forces damage on Tornadus-T faster. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on Clodsire to negate its weakness to opposing Spikes teams, although Leftovers are also viable to increase Clodsire's longevity. Unaware is preferred over Water Absorb to negate Clodsire's passivity against setup sweepers, and Water Absorb does little to help against the likes of Mega Swampert and Gastrodon. Tera Dark grants Clodsire a Ghost resistance, which helps against Choice Specs Dragapult and Gholdengo, especially if using Poison Jab against the latter. It also grants Clodsire with a Pursuit resistance against the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, which can both exploit its physical frailty. Clodsire fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its special walling and entry hazard support. As Clodsire is weak to most physical attackers such as Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Dragonite, teammates that can cover them, such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Buzzwole, make for good partners. In return, Clodsire can switch into Electric-type attacks for the former, and powerful special attackers such as Dragapult for the latter two. Pokemon that benefit from Spikes support, such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo, also pair well with Clodsire, as Spikes puts pressure on checks to them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar. In return, Clodsire appreciates these teammates being able to make more immediate progress. Knock Off users such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T as well as Weavile and Mega Scizor pair well with Clodsire, crippling Heavy-Duty Boots users such as opposing Clodsire and Toxapex, giving Clodsire's entry hazards support a greater impact.

Offensive.description: Great Tusk possesses a lot of invaluable traits with its amazing physical bulk, solid defensive typing, and role compression, all contributing to making it a good Pokemon. Earthquake can be used over Headlong Rush to have a strong STAB without drawbacks, but the power difference is noticeable. Stealth Rock can be used over Close Combat if the team lacks a Stealth Rock setter, but leaves Great Tusk unable to dent Rotom-W and Ting-Lu. Rapid Spin is essential, since it both boosts Great Tusk's Speed and clears entry hazards, which it won’t have a hard time doing against common hazard setters like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Icium Z + Ice Spinner lets it destroy switch-ins like Zapdos and Tornadus-T while also chipping down Moltres for a good amount of damage. Tera Water lets it emergency check Urshifu-R, while Tera Ground lets it deal large amounts of damage with Headlong Rush against Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Tera Steel lets Great Tusk eat a hit from Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant in a pinch, but gaining a Fighting weakness isn’t so desirable. Great Tusk hates having to deal with Zapdos and Moltres due to being threatened by Static and Flame Body, so Pokemon that can deal with them, such as Tapu Koko and Mega Tyranitar, are appreciated. In return, it clears hazards for both of them and beats their checks like Ferrothorn and Ting-Lu.

Defensive.description: Defensively, Great Tusk is a behemoth that is able to shrug off hits from threats like Mega Lopunny and Dragonite while providing the team with good utility options. Ice Spinner helps Great Tusk to not be fodder against Gliscor, Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Body Press lets it deal with Mega Lopunny and pressure Ferrothorn. 56 Speed EVs let it outspeed Garchomp after one speed boost from Rapid Spin. Tera Water lets it check Pokemon like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-RS in a pinch. Tera Dragon allows it to check Ogerpon-W, and deal with Heatran better. Tera Poison provides a useful Toxic immunity. Great Tusk is often set up fodder for Pokemon like aforementioned Iron Valiant, so Pokemon that can deal with it, like Volcarona and Galarian Slowking, are appriciated. In return, it checks Mega Tyranitar and Gliscor for them while also providing Rapid Spin support.

Defensive Bulk Up.description: Bulk Up boosts Great Tusk’s already high Attack and Defense even further, allowing it to brute force past would-be checks like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and opposing Great Tusk, turning them into set-up fodder with Terastallization. Earthquake is chosen over Headlong Rush, as the damage is sufficient with Bulk Up boosts, and the Defense and Special Defense drops can make Great Tusk easier to revenge kill. Ice Spinner lets it break past Pokemon like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Landorus. Rapid Spin acts as a secondary boosting move for Great Tusk, alleviating its mediocre Speed tier and allowing it to sweep undeterred. The given EV spread allows Great Tusk to outspeed Ogerpon-W after a Rapid Spin boost, with the rest used to maximize its physical bulk. Tera Poison prevents Great Tusk from being hit by Toxic while providing crucial resistances to Fairy- and Fighting-type attacks. Tera Electric provides a Flying resistance, allowing Great Tusk to use Zapdos and Tornadus-T as setup fodder while also preventing it from getting paralyzed by Static. Tera Steel combines the Flying resistance from Electric with the Fairy resistance and Toxic immunity from Poison while adding on a Psychic resistance at the cost of being weak to Fighting. Due to its relatively low Speed tier even after a boost, Great Tusk will need help against revenge killers like Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, so Pokemon that can handle the two, such as Mega Scizor, Slowking-G, and Heatran, are appreciated. A more offensive set utilising Booster Energy can also be used on hyper offense teams, but it is generally less effective compared to other choices.

Choice Band.description: STAB U-turn and First Impression combined with a massive Attack stat make Slither Wing a solid wallbreaker, revenge killer, and pivot. First Impression clears Pokemon such as Kartana while also denting Bug-resistant Pokemon such as Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. U-turn lets Slither Wing obtain momentum while also chipping switch-ins like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T. Flare Blitz tears through Gholdengo and is Slither Wing's strongest attack against Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Earthquake hits Pokemon like Toxapex and Skeledirge while still threatening Gholdengo as well. Tera Bug bolsters First Impression's power to high levels, maximizing Slither Wing's revenge killing potential and enabling it to spread much more chip damage with U-turn; however, it gains a Stealth Rock weakness. Slither Wing pairs well with Mega Charizard Y, as it enables Protosynthesis, which lets Slither Wing threaten the opposition more often. It also boosts Flare Blitz, letting it dent Landorus-T and Gliscor better. In return, Mega Charizard Y threatens Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. Special wallbreakers that wear down Slither Wing checks such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Koko pair well with it; they also benefit from Slither Wing breaking their checks. Slither Wing lures in Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite, so Pokemon such as Weavile and Tapu Koko pair well with it, both notably forcing Dragonite to Terastallize into the Normal-type and making it prone to First Impression.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: With fantastic defensive and offensive stats, Iron Hands can act as a bulky setup sweeper or a strong wallbreaker for its team. Due to its amazing bulk, Iron Hands is able to setup Swords Dance reliably to punch holes through foes more easily. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to hit Gliscor, Landorus-T and Garchomp super effectively, complementing its STAB moves nicely. Iron Hands can use Tera Water to take otherwise super effective hits from the likes of Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Great Tusk, alongside gaining a resistance to Water-type moves, allowing Iron Hands to answer common rain abusers including Mega Swampert and Barraskewda, while Tera Flying makes Iron Hands immune to Ground-type moves from the likes of Landorus-T and Garchomp. The given EV spread allows Iron Hands to survive an unboosted Tapu Lele Psychic from full HP, while the Speed investment lets Iron Hands outspeed Clefable. Because of Iron Hands's poor Speed but fantastic bulk, it's more suited to bulky offense and balance teams as opposed to hyper offensive team structures. Pokemon like Landorus-T, Gliscor and Tornadus-T are fantastic teammates because they can switch into the strong Ground-type moves that threaten Iron Hands such as Great Tusk's Headlong Rush; in addition, they can all remove entry hazards, which is appreciated by Tera Flying variants, and the former two are also able to set hazards, helping Iron Hands break through teams more easily. Rillaboom can setup Grassy Terrain, weakening opposing Earthquake and giving Iron Hands more passive recovery alongside Leftovers while weakening the defensive Ground-types that could stop Iron Hands, although it should be noted Tera Flying variants will not benefit from the terrain. Defensive Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Iron Crown are good teammates because they can come in on the Psychic- and Fairy- types that Iron Hands dislikes, such as Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Latios. Alomomola boosts Iron Hands's longevity with Wish while being a good answer to Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp. Strong special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Serperior, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona appreciate Iron Hands breaking through common special walls like Galarian Slowking, Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Gliscor, and in return they break through physically defensive walls like Landorus-T and Dondozo.
